In every case the characters representing the darkness and terror of winter are defeated by those personifying the light and life of spring; the play ends with general clowning and gaiety. The local version of the Pace Egg is always performed at Easter time. Wardle Village (two miles from Rochdale's town centre) currently keeps this piece of local folklore alive. The play is performed annually in the village on Good Friday - approx. 30 performances of the ten minute play - acted against the moorland background. In keeping with tradition, eggs are collected, which are divided amongst the elderly in the community. In recent years, money has also been collected, which has been used to help the elderly villagers.
